segment.source: Adaptive tile templates are a new feature in Windows 10, allowing you to design your own tile notification content using a simple and flexible markup language that adapts to different screen densities.
segment.target: Adaptive tile templates are a new feature in Windows 10, allowing you to design your own tile notification content using a simple and flexible markup language that adapts to different screen densities.

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Adaptive tile templates are a new feature in Windows 10, allowing you to design your own tile notification content using a simple and flexible markup language that adapts to different screen densities.
segment.target: Adaptive tile templates are a new feature in Windows 10, allowing you to design your own tile notification content using a simple and flexible markup language that adapts to different screen densities.

segment.source: This article tells you how to create adaptive live tiles for your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This article tells you how to create adaptive live tiles for your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: For the complete list of adaptive elements and attributes, see the Adaptive tiles schema.
segment.target: For the complete list of adaptive elements and attributes, see the Adaptive tiles schema.

segment.source: (If you'd like, you can still use the preset templates from the Windows 8 tile template catalog when designing notifications for Windows 10.)
segment.target: (If you'd like, you can still use the preset templates from the Windows 8 tile template catalog when designing notifications for Windows 10.)

segment.source: If you'd like to use C# instead of XML to generate notifications, install the NuGet package named NotificationsExtensions.
segment.target: If you'd like to use C# instead of XML to generate notifications, install the NuGet package named NotificationsExtensions.

segment.source: The C# samples provided in this article use NotificationsExtensions.
segment.target: The C# samples provided in this article use NotificationsExtensions.

segment.source: This free UWP app helps you design adaptive live tiles by providing an instant visual preview of your tile as you edit it, similar to Visual Studio's XAML editor/design view.
segment.target: This free UWP app helps you design adaptive live tiles by providing an instant visual preview of your tile as you edit it, similar to Visual Studio's XAML editor/design view.

segment.source: You can read this blog post for more information, and you can download Notifications Visualizer here.
segment.target: You can read this blog post for more information, and you can download Notifications Visualizer here.

segment.source: Adaptive templates are designed to work across different form factors and notification types.
segment.target: Adaptive templates are designed to work across different form factors and notification types.

segment.source: Elements such as group and subgroup link together content and don't imply a particular visual behavior on their own.
segment.target: Elements such as group and subgroup link together content and don't imply a particular visual behavior on their own.

segment.source: The final appearance of a notification should be based on the specific device on which it will appear, whether it's phone, tablet, or desktop, or another device.
segment.target: The final appearance of a notification should be based on the specific device on which it will appear, whether it's phone, tablet, or desktop, or another device.

segment.source: Hints are optional attributes that can be added to elements in order to achieve a specific visual behavior.
segment.target: Hints are optional attributes that can be added to elements in order to achieve a specific visual behavior.

segment.source: Hints can be device-specific or notification-specific.
segment.target: Hints can be device-specific or notification-specific.

segment.source: This example demonstrates what the adaptive tile templates can produce.
segment.target: This example demonstrates what the adaptive tile templates can produce.

segment.source: Content for each tile size is individually specified in separate binding elements within the XML payload.
segment.target: Content for each tile size is individually specified in separate binding elements within the XML payload.

segment.source: Choose the target size by setting the template attribute to one of the following values:
segment.target: Choose the target size by setting the template attribute to one of the following values:

segment.source: For a single tile notification XML payload, provide binding elements for each tile size that you'd like to support, as shown in this example:
segment.target: For a single tile notification XML payload, provide binding elements for each tile size that you'd like to support, as shown in this example:

segment.source: adaptive tile sizes: small, medium, wide, and large
segment.target: adaptive tile sizes: small, medium, wide, and large

segment.source: You can control the branding on the bottom of a live tile (the display name and corner logo) by using the branding attribute on the notification payload.
segment.target: You can control the branding on the bottom of a live tile (the display name and corner logo) by using the branding attribute on the notification payload.

segment.source: You can choose to display "none," only the "name," only the "logo," or both with "nameAndLogo."
segment.target: You can choose to display "none," only the "name," only the "logo," or both with "nameAndLogo."

segment.source: Note Windows Phone doesn't support the corner logo, so "logo" and "nameAndLogo" default to "name" on phone.
segment.target: Note Windows Phone doesn't support the corner logo, so "logo" and "nameAndLogo" default to "name" on phone.

segment.source: Branding can be applied for specific tile sizes one of two ways:
segment.target: Branding can be applied for specific tile sizes one of two ways:

segment.source: By applying the attribute on the binding element
segment.target: By applying the attribute on the binding element

segment.source: By applying the attribute on the visual element, which affects the entire notification payload If you don't specify branding for a binding, it will use the branding that's provided on the visual element.
segment.target: By applying the attribute on the visual element, which affects the entire notification payload If you don't specify branding for a binding, it will use the branding that's provided on the visual element.

segment.source: If you don't specify the branding in your notification payload, the base tile's properties will determine the branding.
segment.target: If you don't specify the branding in your notification payload, the base tile's properties will determine the branding.

segment.source: If the base tile shows the display name, then the branding will default to "name."
segment.target: If the base tile shows the display name, then the branding will default to "name."

segment.source: Otherwise, the branding will default to "none" if the display name isn't shown.
segment.target: Otherwise, the branding will default to "none" if the display name isn't shown.

segment.source: Note This is a change from Windows 8.x, in which the default branding was "logo."
segment.target: Note This is a change from Windows 8.x, in which the default branding was "logo."

segment.source: You can override the display name of a notification by entering the text string of your choice with the displayName attribute.
segment.target: You can override the display name of a notification by entering the text string of your choice with the displayName attribute.

segment.source: As with branding, you can specify this on the visual element, which affects the entire notification payload, or on the binding element, which only affects individual tiles.
segment.target: As with branding, you can specify this on the visual element, which affects the entire notification payload, or on the binding element, which only affects individual tiles.

segment.source: The text element is used to display text.
segment.target: The text element is used to display text.

segment.source: You can use hints to modify how text appears.
segment.target: You can use hints to modify how text appears.

segment.source: By default, text doesn't wrap and will continue off the edge of the tile.
segment.target: By default, text doesn't wrap and will continue off the edge of the tile.

segment.source: Use the hint-wrap attribute to set text wrapping on a text element.
segment.target: Use the hint-wrap attribute to set text wrapping on a text element.

segment.source: You can also control the minimum and maximum number of lines by using hint-minLines and hint-maxLines, both of which accept positive integers.
segment.target: You can also control the minimum and maximum number of lines by using hint-minLines and hint-maxLines, both of which accept positive integers.

segment.source: Styles control the font size, color, and weight of text elements.
segment.target: Styles control the font size, color, and weight of text elements.

segment.source: There are a number of available styles, including a "subtle" variation of each style that sets the opacity to 60%, which usually makes the text color a shade of light gray.
segment.target: There are a number of available styles, including a "subtle" variation of each style that sets the opacity to 60%, which usually makes the text color a shade of light gray.

segment.source: Note The style defaults to caption if hint-style isn't specified.
segment.target: Note The style defaults to caption if hint-style isn't specified.

segment.source: These variations reduce the line height so that content above and below come much closer to the text.
segment.target: These variations reduce the line height so that content above and below come much closer to the text.

segment.source: Each style has a subtle variation that gives the text a 60% opacity, which usually makes the text color a shade of light gray.
segment.target: Each style has a subtle variation that gives the text a 60% opacity, which usually makes the text color a shade of light gray.

segment.source: Text can be horizontally aligned left, center, or right.
segment.target: Text can be horizontally aligned left, center, or right.

segment.source: In left-to-right languages like English, text defaults to left-aligned.
segment.target: In left-to-right languages like English, text defaults to left-aligned.

segment.source: In right-to-left languages like Arabic, text defaults to right-aligned.
segment.target: In right-to-left languages like Arabic, text defaults to right-aligned.

segment.source: You can manually set alignment with the hint-align attribute on elements.
segment.target: You can manually set alignment with the hint-align attribute on elements.

segment.source: Groups allow you to semantically declare that the content inside the group is related and must be displayed in its entirety for the content to make sense.
segment.target: Groups allow you to semantically declare that the content inside the group is related and must be displayed in its entirety for the content to make sense.

segment.source: For example, you might have two text elements, a header, and a subheader, and it would not make sense for only the header to be shown.
segment.target: For example, you might have two text elements, a header, and a subheader, and it would not make sense for only the header to be shown.

segment.source: By grouping those elements inside a subgroup, the elements will either all be displayed (if they can fit) or not be displayed at all (because they can't fit).
segment.target: By grouping those elements inside a subgroup, the elements will either all be displayed (if they can fit) or not be displayed at all (because they can't fit).

segment.source: To provide the best experience across devices and screens, provide multiple groups.
segment.target: To provide the best experience across devices and screens, provide multiple groups.

segment.source: Having multiple groups allows your tile to adapt to larger screens.
segment.target: Having multiple groups allows your tile to adapt to larger screens.

segment.source: Note The only valid child of a group is a subgroup.
segment.target: Note The only valid child of a group is a subgroup.

segment.source: Subgroups also allow you to divide data into semantic sections within a group.
segment.target: Subgroups also allow you to divide data into semantic sections within a group.

segment.source: For live tiles, this visually translates to columns.
segment.target: For live tiles, this visually translates to columns.

segment.source: The hint-weight attribute lets you to control the widths of columns.
segment.target: The hint-weight attribute lets you to control the widths of columns.

segment.source: The value of hint-weight is expressed as a weighted proportion of available space, which is identical to GridUnitType.Star behavior.
segment.target: The value of hint-weight is expressed as a weighted proportion of available space, which is identical to GridUnitType.Star behavior.

segment.source: For equal-width columns, assign each weight to 1.
segment.target: For equal-width columns, assign each weight to 1.

segment.source: To make one column twice as large as another column, assign the smaller column a weight of 1 and the larger column a weight of 2.
segment.target: To make one column twice as large as another column, assign the smaller column a weight of 1 and the larger column a weight of 2.

segment.source: subgroups, one column twice the size of the other
segment.target: subgroups, one column twice the size of the other

segment.source: If you want your first column to take up 20% of the total width and your second column to take up 80% of the total width, assign the first weight to 20 and the second weight to 80.
segment.target: If you want your first column to take up 20% of the total width and your second column to take up 80% of the total width, assign the first weight to 20 and the second weight to 80.

segment.source: If your total weights equal 100, they'll act as percentages.
segment.target: If your total weights equal 100, they'll act as percentages.

segment.source: Note An 8-pixel margin is automatically added between the columns.
segment.target: Note An 8-pixel margin is automatically added between the columns.

segment.source: When you have more than two subgroups, you should specify the hint-weight, which only accepts positive integers.
segment.target: When you have more than two subgroups, you should specify the hint-weight, which only accepts positive integers.

segment.source: If you don't specify hint-weight for the first subgroup, it will be assigned a weight of 50.
segment.target: If you don't specify hint-weight for the first subgroup, it will be assigned a weight of 50.

segment.source: The next subgroup that doesn't have a specified hint-weight will be assigned a weight equal to 100 minus the sum of the preceding weights, or to 1 if the result is zero.
segment.target: The next subgroup that doesn't have a specified hint-weight will be assigned a weight equal to 100 minus the sum of the preceding weights, or to 1 if the result is zero.

segment.source: The remaining subgroups that don't have specified hint-weights will be assigned a weight of 1.
segment.target: The remaining subgroups that don't have specified hint-weights will be assigned a weight of 1.

segment.source: Here's sample code for a weather tile that shows how you can achieve a tile with five columns of equal width:
segment.target: Here's sample code for a weather tile that shows how you can achieve a tile with five columns of equal width:

segment.source: The image element is used to display images on the tile notification.
segment.target: The image element is used to display images on the tile notification.

segment.source: Images can be placed inline within the tile content (default), as a background image behind your content, or as a peek image that animates in from the top of the notification.
segment.target: Images can be placed inline within the tile content (default), as a background image behind your content, or as a peek image that animates in from the top of the notification.

segment.source: Note There are restrictions on the file size and dimensions of images.
segment.target: Note There are restrictions on the file size and dimensions of images.

segment.source: With no extra behaviors specified, images will uniformly shrink or expand to fill the available width.
segment.target: With no extra behaviors specified, images will uniformly shrink or expand to fill the available width.

segment.source: The sample below shows a tile using two columns and inline images.
segment.target: The sample below shows a tile using two columns and inline images.

segment.source: The inline images stretch to fill the width of the column.
segment.target: The inline images stretch to fill the width of the column.

segment.source: Images placed in the binding root, or in the first group, will also stretch to fit the available height.
segment.target: Images placed in the binding root, or in the first group, will also stretch to fit the available height.

segment.source: Images can be set to align left, center, or right using the hint-align attribute.
segment.target: Images can be set to align left, center, or right using the hint-align attribute.

segment.source: This will also cause images to display at their native resolution instead of stretching to fill width.
segment.target: This will also cause images to display at their native resolution instead of stretching to fill width.

segment.source: By default, inline images have an 8-pixel margin between any content above or below the image.
segment.target: By default, inline images have an 8-pixel margin between any content above or below the image.

segment.source: This margin can be removed by using the hint-removeMargin attribute on the image.
segment.target: This margin can be removed by using the hint-removeMargin attribute on the image.

segment.source: However, images always retain the 8-pixel margin from the edge of the tile, and subgroups (columns) always retain the 8-pixel padding between columns.
segment.target: However, images always retain the 8-pixel margin from the edge of the tile, and subgroups (columns) always retain the 8-pixel padding between columns.

segment.source: Images can be cropped into a circle using the hint-crop attribute, which currently only supports the values "none" (default) or "circle."
segment.target: Images can be cropped into a circle using the hint-crop attribute, which currently only supports the values "none" (default) or "circle."

segment.source: To set a background image, place an image element in the root of the binding and set the placement attribute to "background."
segment.target: To set a background image, place an image element in the root of the binding and set the placement attribute to "background."

segment.source: Additionally, you can set a black overlay on your background image using hint-overlay, which accepts integers from 0-100, with 0 being no overlay and 100 being full black overlay.
segment.target: Additionally, you can set a black overlay on your background image using hint-overlay, which accepts integers from 0-100, with 0 being no overlay and 100 being full black overlay.

segment.source: example of an image hint overlay
segment.target: example of an image hint overlay

segment.source: You can specify an image that "peeks" in from the top of the tile.
segment.target: You can specify an image that "peeks" in from the top of the tile.

segment.source: The peek image uses an animation to slide down/up from the top of the tile, peeking into view, and then later sliding back out to reveal the main content on the tile.
segment.target: The peek image uses an animation to slide down/up from the top of the tile, peeking into view, and then later sliding back out to reveal the main content on the tile.

segment.source: To set a peek image, place an image element in the root of the binding, and set the placement attribute to "peek."
segment.target: To set a peek image, place an image element in the root of the binding, and set the placement attribute to "peek."

segment.source: Circle crop for peek and background images
segment.target: Circle crop for peek and background images

segment.source: Use the following attribute on peek and background images to do a circle crop:
segment.target: Use the following attribute on peek and background images to do a circle crop:

segment.source: The result will look like this:
segment.target: The result will look like this:

segment.source: circle crop for peek and background image
segment.target: circle crop for peek and background image

segment.source: Use both peek and background image
segment.target: Use both peek and background image

segment.source: To use both a peek and a background image on a tile notification, specify both a peek image and a background image in your notification payload.
segment.target: To use both a peek and a background image on a tile notification, specify both a peek image and a background image in your notification payload.

segment.source: The result will look like this:
segment.target: The result will look like this:

segment.source: peek and background image used together
segment.target: peek and background image used together

segment.source: Use hint-overlay on a peek image
segment.target: Use hint-overlay on a peek image

segment.source: You can use hint-overlay on a peek image to add opacity and make the tile's display name more legible.
segment.target: You can use hint-overlay on a peek image to add opacity and make the tile's display name more legible.

segment.source: If you specify hint-overlay on the binding element, the overlay will be applied to both the background and the peek image.
segment.target: If you specify hint-overlay on the binding element, the overlay will be applied to both the background and the peek image.

segment.source: You can also apply hint-overlay to an image element that has placement="peek" or placement="background" to have discrete opacity levels for each of those images.
segment.target: You can also apply hint-overlay to an image element that has placement="peek" or placement="background" to have discrete opacity levels for each of those images.

segment.source: If you don't specify an overlay, the background image opacity defaults to 20% and the peek image opacity defaults to 0%.
segment.target: If you don't specify an overlay, the background image opacity defaults to 20% and the peek image opacity defaults to 0%.

segment.source: This example shows a background image at 20% opacity (left) and at 0% opacity (right):
segment.target: This example shows a background image at 20% opacity (left) and at 0% opacity (right):

segment.source: You can control the vertical alignment of content on your tile by using the hint-textStacking attribute on both the binding element and subgroup element.
segment.target: You can control the vertical alignment of content on your tile by using the hint-textStacking attribute on both the binding element and subgroup element.

segment.source: By default, everything is vertically aligned to the top, but you can also align content to the bottom or center.
segment.target: By default, everything is vertically aligned to the top, but you can also align content to the bottom or center.

segment.source: When applied at the binding level, text stacking sets the vertical alignment of the notification content as a whole, aligning in the available vertical space above the branding/badge area.
segment.target: When applied at the binding level, text stacking sets the vertical alignment of the notification content as a whole, aligning in the available vertical space above the branding/badge area.

segment.source: When applied at the subgroup level, text stacking sets the vertical alignment of the subgroup (column) content, aligning in the available vertical space within the entire group.
segment.target: When applied at the subgroup level, text stacking sets the vertical alignment of the subgroup (column) content, aligning in the available vertical space within the entire group.
